abstract: Jamaat-ud-Dawa, charity wing of Pakistani militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba, begins ambulance service in Karachi, in telling sign that some militant groups continue to be tolerated by government; some view unveiling of service functions as calculated display of group's ability to operate with impunity.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the group that waged the deadly 2008 Mumbai attacks, inaugurated an ambulance service run by the group’s charity wing, Jamaat-ud-Dawa, in Karachi.

byline.contributor: Saba Imtiaz reported from Karachi, and Declan Walsh from London.
byline.original: By SABA IMTIAZ and DECLAN WALSH

snippet: On Monday, Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the group that waged the deadly 2008 Mumbai attacks, inaugurated an ambulance service run by the group’s charity wing, Jamaat-ud-Dawa, in Karachi.

headline.main: In Pakistan, a Charity Project Points to Official Tolerance of Militants
headline.print_headline: In Pakistan, a Charity Project Points to Official Tolerance of Militants
